title: Linear Models and Endogeneity in Finance
text:
Theory, hypotheses, and operationalisation
What is a hypothesis?

A hypothesis is a proposed explanation for a phenomenon or a prediction of a possible causal correlation
It is a tentative answer to a research question that guides the direction of study and investigation
Its formulation is guided by existing (economic) theory
A well-constructed hypothesis is testable, meaning it can be supported or rejected through experimentation
crumbs: Linear Models and Endogeneity in Finance

title: Linear Models and Endogeneity in Finance
text:
Theory, hypotheses, and operationalisation
How do we test a hypothesis?

Stepst-testVisual



We need a baseline to test against: The null hypothesis (\(H_0\))
Why null? It states that there is no effect or no difference, which serves as a baseline assumption

\(H_0\) is what you test your \(H_1\) against, e.g.¬†\(H_0 = 0\)
\(H_1\) is the/your alternative hypothesis - what you might believe to be true

A statistical test rejects \(H_0\) if there is enough evidence against it

If we reject \(H_0\), we accept \(H_1\)




The t-test measures how far the sample mean is away from \(H_0\)
Hypothesis:

One-sided (\(H_0 \leq 0\), \(H_1>0\)): \(t = \frac{X-0}{SE(X)}\)
Two-sided (\(H_0 = 0\), \(H_1 \neq 0\)): \(t = \frac{X_{treated}-X_{control}}{SE(X_{treated}-X_{control})}\)
crumbs: Linear Models and Endogeneity in Finance

title: Linear Models and Endogeneity in Finance
text:
Causal inference
A small Becksperiment
Research question: Does beer affect performance?

\(H_0\): Beer consumption does not affect performance
\(H_1\): Beer consumption affects performance



Sometimes \(H_1\) is referred to as a non-directional hypothesis. This means that it does not specify the direction of the effect. Theory allows for the affect to be positive or negative.

Simple group comparison

The results suggest that, on average, beer drinking improves grades.

title: Linear Models and Endogeneity in Finance
text:
The gold standard: Experiments
Why is randomization so important?

Controlling variation in the causal variable, e.g.¬†beer drinking
Makes sure that the treatment and control group are similar along observable and unobservable dimensions
The only difference between the two groups is the treatment
This allows us to attribute any difference in outcomes to the treatment
No selection bias (endogeneity issue)



Another term for Experiments is Randomized Controlled Trials (RCTs).
crumbs: Linear Models and Endogeneity in Finance

title: Linear Models and Endogeneity in Finance
text:
The gold standard: Experiments
Designing and analyzing experiments
Types of experiments:

Field experiments

aim to be as similar as possible to real-world decision situations

A/B testing

aim to evaluate different versions of the same product

Lab experiments

are carried out in an artificial environment, usually a computer lab




For more in-depth information on experiments and other causal inference methods, see B√©k√©s and K√©zdi (2021).

title: Linear Models and Endogeneity in Finance

The gold standard: Experiments
External and internal validity

Internal validity

Extent to which experiment identifies causal effect of treatment

External validity

Extent to which results generalize to other situations





üö®üíºüß† Trade-off

High external validity more likely achieved in real world situation
High internal validity more likely achieved in controlled situation
How well does the result from ‚Äúcontrolled situation‚Äù generalize to the real world?

title: Linear Models and Endogeneity in Finance
text:
Experiments in practice

Design can be complicated

Intention to treat versus actual treatment

Experiments need careful planning

Results uninformative or misleading if poorly designed

Analysis is relatively simple to do and to communicate



When compliance is not perfect the intention to treat effect is the effect of being assigned to the treatment group, not the effect of actually receiving the treatment.

In the experiment you control‚Ä¶

who receives the treatment (the treatment group),‚Ä¶

Potential trade-off between internal and external validity

title: Linear Models and Endogeneity in Finance
text:
Natural experiments
What is a natural experiment?

A natural experiment is an observational study that uses a naturally occurring event to assign treatment and control groups
The event is not controlled by the researcher
The event is not a random assignment, but it is as-if random
Some prominent examples of natural experiments are:

Military draft lotteries
Allocation of water to diÔ¨Äerent houses
Economic shocks

title: Linear Models and Endogeneity in Finance
text:
Control variables
What are control variables?

They are used to control for confounding variables that may bias the estimated effect of the treatment on the outcome
Control variables are not the same as instrumental variables (IVs)
The interpretation of the treatment effect is conditional on the control variables
Still the treatment effect is not the same as the causal effect, if the treatment is not randomly assigned
‚ÄúJust‚Äù a correlation between treatment and outcome

title: Linear Models and Endogeneity in Finance
text:
Ordinary Least Squares (OLS)
OLS Assumption
OLS‚Äôs key assumptions to produce consistent estimates

Random sample of observations on Y and X
A mean zero error term (\(\epsilon\)) with a constant variance
No linear relationship among the explanatory variables, i.e.¬†no perfect collinearity
An error term that is uncorrelated with each explanatory variable, i.e.¬†\(Cov(x_i ,\epsilon ) = 0\)
An error term with zero mean conditional on the explanatory variables, i.e.¬†\(E( \epsilon | X ) = 0\)
crumbs: Linear Models and Endogeneity in Finance

title: Linear Models and Endogeneity in Finance
text:
Ordinary Least Squares (OLS)
OLS Assumption (1)

Random sample of observations on Y and X

This assumption can be relaxed
One need to assume only that the error term is independent of the sample selection mechanism conditional on the covariates (i.e., control variables)

No Biggie!
crumbs: Linear Models and Endogeneity in Finance

title: Linear Models and Endogeneity in Finance
text:
Ordinary Least Squares (OLS)
OLS Assumption (2)

A mean zero error term (\(\epsilon\)) with a constant variance

A nonzero mean for the error term simply gets absorbed by the intercept

No Biggie!

The variance of the error term is not constant if it increases with one of the dependent variables‚Ä¶ (a.k.a. Heteroscedasticity)
We will always use robust standard errors that take care of that issue, hence‚Ä¶

No Biggie!
crumbs: Linear Models and Endogeneity in Finance

title: Linear Models and Endogeneity in Finance
text:
Ordinary Least Squares (OLS)
OLS Assumption (3)

No linear relationship among the explanatory variables, i.e.¬†no perfect collinearity

No Biggie! OLS does not run!


And what about, high (but not perfect) collinearity, a.k.a. multicollinearity? - Interpretation of coefficients problematic, since c.p. does not work anymore
crumbs: Linear Models and Endogeneity in Finance

title: Linear Models and Endogeneity in Finance
text:
Ordinary Least Squares (OLS)
OLS Assumption (4 & 5)

An error term that is uncorrelated with each explanatory variable, i.e.¬†\(Cov(x_i ,epsilon ) = 0\)
An error term with zero mean conditional on the explanatory variables, i.e.¬†\(E( epsilon | X ) = 0\)


No way to empirically test whether a variable is correlated with the regression error term because the error term is unobservable
This problem is called ENDOGENEITY
Sources of endogeneity:

Measurement error in the dependent or independent variable
Simultaneity
Omitted variable bias (recall selection bias in the example)
crumbs: Linear Models and Endogeneity in Finance

title: Linear Models and Endogeneity in Finance
text:
Fixed Effects
What are fixed effects?

Common practice in panel data analysis
Any time-invariant characteristic that cannot be observed in the data = fixed effect
Fixed effects alleviate concerns that time invariant characteristics drive the results
They DO NOT solve endogeneity issues (more on that in the next lectures)
Use with caution! Do not ‚Äúfix effect away‚Äù what you want to measure, i.e.¬†understanding cross-sectional variation in a variable
Very common to include firm and year fixed effects
crumbs: Linear Models and Endogeneity in Finance

title: Linear Models and Endogeneity in Finance
text:
Fixed Effects
Fixed Effects - Example
\[y_{i,t} = \beta_0 + \beta_1X_{i,t} + \epsilon_{i, t}\]
The error term \(u_{i,t}\) includes an omitted variable that is constant for each \(i\)
\[u_{i,t} = \epsilon_{i, t} + c_{i}\]
Include separate intercept for each \(i\) or ‚Äúdeviations-from-individual-means regression‚Äù
\[\left(y_{i,t} - \frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=1}^{T}y_{i,t} \right) = \left( \beta_0 - \frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=1}^{T}y_{i,t} \right) + \left(\beta_1X_{i,t} - \frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=1}^{T}X_{i,t} \right) + \left(\epsilon_{i,t} - \frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=1}^{T}\epsilon_{i,t}  \right)\]
Problem solved, because‚Ä¶
\[c_{i} - \frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=1}^{T}c_{i} = 0\]
crumbs: Linear Models and Endogeneity in Finance

title: Linear Models and Endogeneity in Finance
text:
Standard Errors
What is the problem, anyways?

Statistical significance (a.k.a. inference) (\(t\)-stat) boils down to two ingredients: \(\beta\) and standard error
Failure to control for within-cluster error correlation can lead to very misleadingly small standard errors ‚áí large t-statistics (and low p-values)
Inference breaks down
crumbs: Linear Models and Endogeneity in Finance

title: Linear Models and Endogeneity in Finance
text:
Standard Errors
Best Practices

Always use robust standard errors (solves heteroscedasticity issues)
Rule of thumb I: Cluster at the level of the treatment/‚Äúshock‚Äù, e.g.¬†treatment is on state-level (new law) ‚áí cluster standard errors at state
Be careful: Less than ‚âà 30 clusters makes standard errors too small
Rule of thumb II: Check robustness of different cluster methods ‚áí report most conservative one

For more details see, e.g.¬†Petersen (2009), Abadie et al.¬†(2017), Cameron & Miller
crumbs: Linear Models and Endogeneity in Finance

title: Linear Models and Endogeneity in Finance
text:
Interpretation of coefficients
Functional Forms








Name
Functional form
Interpretation \(\beta_1\)




Linear
\(Y = \beta_0 +\beta_1X + \epsilon\)
Average change of Y by one unit change in X \(=\beta_1\)


Log-linear
\(ln(Y) = \beta_0 +\beta_1X + \epsilon\)
Average change of Y by one unit change in X \(\approx100 \times \beta_1\)%1


Log-log
\(ln(Y) = \beta_0 +\beta_1ln(X) + \epsilon\)
% change in mean Y associated with a one percent change in X (a.k.a. elasticity), (c.p.) \(=\beta_1\)



Exact calculation: \(100 \times (e^{\beta_1}-1)\)
crumbs: Linear Models and Endogeneity in Finance

title: Data Analytics in Finance
text:
Welcome to the Data Analytics in Finance course materials. This website contains all the lecture slides, assignments, and resources for the course.


This course equips students with essential research skills in finance, including data analytics, scientific methods, and econometric techniques. Students will learn how to critically assess academic research, replicate findings, and conduct their own analyses.



By the end of this course, students will be able to:

Apply appropriate data management, analysis, and visualization techniques
Critically evaluate models and theories in finance
Understand the scientific method as applied to finance research
Apply commonly used econometric methods for financial applications
Analyze ethical concepts and dilemmas in finance
